comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The small note beside Marconi's picture definitely mentions Clifden. There was a Marconi Station there. Could the second one be Poldhu in Wales (it looks more like Paris).

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Indeed. The note seems to list the call letters for the Marconi stations at Clifden (CDN), Poldhu (PD) and Norddeich (KND). See stations list and article on Norddeich station. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] I'm not sure about the labelled location either. The windows and ceiling height seem incongruous for a steamer of that size. Although, to be fair, the dining room is bigger than I'd have expected. Was looking around the operator for other clues (one way or the other), but nothing stood out. (Although to my eye the rack of keys and the waste basket look a bit too "loose" to stay put on a stormy crossing of the Irish sea. They look more suited to maybe one of the steamship company offices in Waterford itself...)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wireless World was published by the Marconi company. This copy seems to be Vol.1, No.6, September 1913 [not 1916 as on following website] - see it in colour! - www.allposters.co.uk/-sp/Wireless-world-Radios-Magazine-U...

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: I have to say people - that isn't a ship...it's an office building AND if he was a wireless operator on a vessel, surely he would be in uniform?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A small detail: the photo in the nli archive is titled "Marconi Room At Conningbeg", as if Conningbeg is a location, rather than "On the S.S. Conningbeg". where Conningbeg is clearly a ship.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Just to confuse things, there was also a lightship called Coningbeg at Dun Laoghaire. www.flickr.com/photos/chartrouse/3900802339/ and Coningbeg Rock Buoy and Light Ship

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] , I think that ship is the lightship which used to be stationed at Coningbeg Rock. It was only in Dun Laoghaire after it retired, I think.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Those are sash windows - you dont get those on ships!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Carol - can you see an address on the Arnold Calendar in the photo - it would most likely be from somewhere close by? The 1911 Census has a James Arnold Grocer and Spirit merchant Waterford It would be interesting if it was his calendar which could give us a Waterford connection and perhaps add to the suggestions that perhaps it was at the ships office in Waterford?

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: www.wrecksite.eu/imgBrowser.aspx?16713 Was this the SS Coningbeg we're talking about, it was originally called the Clodagh. Though I have to agree the photo doesnt look like a shipboard wireless room (not that I've seen many)

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] That lightship was moored near Coningbeg Rock (south of the Saltee Islands off Kilmore Quay). As you suggest, that rock (and that ship) weren't big enough to sustain an office like that. As with other commenters, the more I look at it, I doubt the photo was taken on any type of vessel. While there could have been a land-based Marconi station called "Coningbeg" (maybe on the Saltee's?), I still recon it's an office in one/other of the shipping company's in Waterford city itself. (I've tried "enhancing" the pin-up papers in the top left of the photo. However, without one of the mythical "enhance and enlarge" photo manipulation suites seen in the movies, I don't think that'll get us much...)

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Looks like the same Marconi photo as noted by blackpoolbeach. www.proton.rmutphysics.com/physics/charud/scibook/electro...

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Have you any photos of Irish whiskey distilleries? Or any photos taken during "The Emergency" (WW2)?

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: Photographs taken during 'The Emergency' would be very interesting, particularly any that are transport related. During this period, to keep their workers employed, Ford of Cork made clogs for the army and also set workers to 'straightening' nails at a rate of 6p an hour. There must be many photographs that tell equally interesting stories.

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: www.marconicalling.com/museum/html/objects/photographs/la... this is the clifden radio room so definitely not the same

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mogey] The Clifden station would probably be a good bit fancier than others, since it was one end of the transatlantic link. Here is a Marconi station in Rosslare on the OS 25" map of 1903, which acted a s a relay between Clifden and Wales. I don't see a place called Coningbeg anywhere on any maps (apart from the rock with the lightship), nor do I see a Marconi station in Waterford. I'm leaning towards the theory that this photo shows the Waterford office of the Clyde shipping company, and that the young man is pretending to be communicating with the Coningbeg for the picture. (Note that his head shows some motion blur, but both his hands are clear: he is neither tapping out Morse nor writing it down!)

comment.author: 60812213@N04
comment._content: Adding my tuppence. The desk on a vessel would contain a lip on the edge. Ships roll, and so do things on the desk. My money is on a building.

comment._content: The Clyde Shipping Company had their own offices in Waterford at 1 Custom House Quay since the 1820s. Streetview

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: This definetly isn't the wireless room at Clifden as it was a single storey building with very different shaped windows - markpadfield.com/marconicalling/museum/html/objects/photo...

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: I'm nearly certain tat the location is in teh Clyde Shipping Company Offices at Custom House Quay, Waterford. The building is still there and has sash windows of a size comparable with teh photo.

comment._content: Have uploaded photo of probable site of shot

comment.author: 60329026@N07
comment._content: I'm inclined to think that this is a posed shot. The operator would not have the pencil in one hand and the other hand on the morse key. To the best of my recall someone who writes with the right hand would also operate the morse key with the same hand. Also this lad is wearing breeches which would suggest that he was more likely to be a messenger attached to the radio room rather than a operator.

comment.author: 96179722@N00
comment._content: I watched a special on Titanic not too long ago that talked about how frivilous the Marconi was considered to be when it was first installed.  All the rich people would write out completely inane messages to send to their friends back on land, like, "Hello, this is sent from the middle of the sea."  It made me think of Twitter.  People sent out stupid messages just because the technology existed and then we found sorta legitimate uses for it.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Any of you interested in Marconi (and within shouting distance of Howth) may like to know about this day-long celebration at the Hurdy Gurdy Radio Museum. It's on Saturday 20 April and the good people there would show you a very good time...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
